title: AI Applications in Manufacturing

author: Bogdan Filipič, Department of Intelligent Systems, Jožef Stefan Institute

segmentation: This talk will be about AI applications in manufacturing and let me.
We introduce myself first in the graphical form like many speakers today.
I also come from the user Steven Institute.
I'm with the Department of Intelligent Systems.
And by intelligent systems we mean computer systems that use or they imitate human intelligence in solving all kinds of problems.
In most cases these are software systems.
Sometimes they also include hardware components.
An example here is the so called ambient intelligence, which is meant to, let's say, recognize activities and similar things in certain environments.
I am sorry.
I am with the Computational Intelligence Group, which concerns itself with nature inspired techniques for solving problems in the areas of search machine learning and optimization.
One of our focuses in particular is a multi objective optimization where multiple objectives are to be considered.

Typically they are conflicting and optimizing or decision-making in this case is means not to search for a single solution that should be optimal, but rather search for tradeoffs we are involved in various research activities in this domain in developing algorithms.
In visualizing the results.
But of course this presentation is.
Not about research today it's about applications.
So regarding the applications that we are involved in, they range first of all in scale from very small components as these we will discuss later on to space engineering.
For example, analyzing mission trajectories for the Japanese space agency somewhere in between there's a number of industrial applications we do, and we apply the techniques that I mentioned.

So what I'm going to do today is I will mention some hot topics in this area, but then illustrate what can be done with AI in manufacturing with three case studies from the projects we were involved in.
So for sure everyone interested in new trends in manufacturing you will be familiar with the concepts like these listed here.
Industry 4.0 smart factories and many many things and systems.
On the other hand, there's a lot of techniques that can be used in these areas, ranging from infrastructural support to various AI techniques and.
Methodology's
Now.

What the profits of these modern technologies promise you is to get many benefits from these technology, ranging from rapid product development, then enhancing production outcomes, advancing process effectiveness, and so on.
Of course, one may wonder how to achieve all these because they are quite often in conflict.
Now if.
We continue.
There are very ambitious predictions.

If you take the reportes by eminent, let's say companies analyzing markets and technology developments, you will find claims like this that mention high expected growth of market shares, incomes and so on.
But on the other hand.
There are also warnings that are putting us on more realistic grounds, like for example why AI is growing and by all resources will continue to maturity.

Confidence return of investment, scaling and connectivity might be slowing mass adoption, so this indicates that although the predictions are very optimistic, the adoption of AI in practice in manufacturing is not that quick as one would expect.
Or AI will make manufacturing operations smarter, but a learning curve comes first by Gartner, and so on.
The final one, the increasing scale of adoption of AI in manufacturing seems more like an evolution rather than an industry disruption, so it is slowly progressing process.
OK with this.
Warnings in mind.
Let's go through some case studies as I promised.
We were quite a lot with steel industry, so one of the processes we are working on is continuous casting of steel, which is the actually the process of steel production.
Most of process worldwide is produced in this way, so it starts with liquid steel that comes out of the firm furnace.
This is then transported to continuous casting device and through the process of heat extraction and solidification.
What we get at the end is this kind of semi products that are then used for various purposes.
This is an example or this is from one of our steel plants.
Just to give you an impression of what's going on.
Now the specific problem here is how to conduct this manufacturing process in order to get high quality product, how to improve or increase the productivity and so on so?
In a very simple way, this can be viewed in the following way.
There is the process and a number of input variables.
We call these process parameters that influence the process.
Then we have certain output variables.
Actually certain criteria we want to meet in order to have the high quality product high productivity.
Minimize the environmental pollution and things like that so in.
In a way, there is knowing the process and having some requirements for the output.
Schematically seeing this problem, one would ask So what are the input parameters that provide these results?

So typical optimization problem which may look simple on this scheme, but in practice it is complex because a number of these process parameters are involved and requirements on the output side are conflicting.
So.

One way of handling such kind of problems is to use the so called simulation based optimization, which is nowadays possible in many manufacturing and other processes because of efficient and reliable numerical simulation of processes and devices.
So steel casting is such an example.
Nowadays, numerical models of this process are reliable enough in order to use them in such a loop to optimize.
The parameter settings based on the requirements a user may have for such a process, so the story goes like this.
We start with some initial solution, which means certain values of process parameters.
Then we go through this loop a number of times, and this loop involves an optimization algorithm and the numerical simulator.
The role of the optimization algorithm is to provide to generate candidate solutions based on the information.
Seen so far and then used simulator as an evaluator of new candidate solutions.
Typically certain quantities are calculated aggregated into a cost function, and this is actually the thing that we want to either minimize or maximize.
In a more general case, we are looking for tradeoffs between the requirements, so after a certain number of iterations, the result is optimized.

So this is a rather general concept, which in this case resulted in, let's say such a software tool being implemented and installed at a steel plant, and the role of this software is to calculate optimized parameter settings with respect to various requirements.
This part where this user interface actually shows.

A number of input variables, a small subset of and on the right hand side there are three output variables and we see there are various solutions possible, and in particular here we have a solution where all these output variables have a certain tradeoff, let's say at around the middle values and this is actually a computational result which is then provided to a.
Decision maker which and who decides about what particular solution to use in a specific case.
Now this depends on a particular situation.
Sometimes quality is more important, sometimes productivity is more important and so on.
Then I will go to the next use case.
This has to do with the production of very small components called commutators.
These are parts of electric Motors as used for example in vehicles.
This is produced in large quantities by a major Slovenian producer that have major market share internationally.
In producing these components.
Now the task here is the following.

These components are produced in a number of stages and output the reliability of these components has to be very high becausw the customers require really very reliable components, so it's just a few in a million can be false.
This is the standard that is present in this industry, so this producer was very much interested in quality control.
Online quality control now where AI can come in in this task so.
The idea is there's a number of work cells and various operations take place in producing these components.
Some key points in this process are especially critical from the point of view of potential failures or errors on these products.
So the producer of these components had the idea of using computer vision in monitoring the quality of these products, and they were.
Even equipped with a team of this kind, but there were some additional things that were required in order to help the computer vision based quality control functional.

First of all, the requirement was to have a reliable, highly accurate model of predicting the quality of these components based on computer vision and another criterion was these models should be very compact and efficient, 'cause the idea was to have a kind of embedded computer architecture in the form of smart cameras.
So the image processing and the prediction of.
Either sufficient quality or error should be really very efficient.
So the idea here was the following one.
One of the characteristics that they were interested in was the quality of this roughness surface.
In here in the center of the component that is the main concern of the production and quality control.
So of course the idea is to take images of these products to extract some features, which is, let's say the first step, the prerequisite for computer vision based control.
But these procedure, the design of the procedure was actually automated.
Actually we involve machine learning to extract OK to predict quality classes, or certain values that were to be predicted.
It was variants of these problems and were classification, some regression type problems.
So each case it was always done on a pre training.
So there was a number of products there.
Images were taken, processed features extracted, and they had known labels for quality classes or the values of the quantities of interest.
Now these were trained then the final models typically were random forests, and the aspect here that involved the optimization part is this one.
It is typically the major concern in data mining and machine learning in general is.
The accuracy now in this case we were, as mentioned, interested in the complexity of the resulting models as well.
So what we see here is a particular study how the models of various complexity vary in their accuracy.
So we see that there's a blue dot there which shows quite large model of let's say 350 nodes.
With quite high accuracy, close to 80% there, this is not the final one.

I must say from the beginning from the initial study for the results I can show, but we can see that by tuning the learning procedure to reduce in smaller models we do not lose much in terms of the classification accuracy, so the final solution was to select a model predictive models that were.
Quite high accuracy, but small complexity.
In order for them to be.
Computationally efficient when deployed on the.
So this really took place, so such a procedure was transferred to embedded computer architecture and test it and implement it online.
OK, the final example would be from the engineering design, where similar concepts are used.
It is not directly manufacturing, but it is related to it.
This has to do with the design of energy supply systems that are based on renewable energy.
So a typical situation here is one can think of a typical configuration of such a system.
And the main components that will be of our interests are these photovoltaic panels and batteries.
And then there is a backup component diesel aggregate which can provide energy where there is none, either from the panels or from the batteries.
And the idea is to design such a system in terms of the configurations in such a way that the certain recording variables are determined, like what is the number of each components?
What are the types, what is the power of the digital aggregate and so on.
So these are potential configurations and the task is to balance between the costs one has with designing I mean.
Installing and operating such a system and the amount of energy such a system provides.
So what we have in.
This case is typically what is sometimes called techno economical situation, so we are balancing between the costs and certain technical characteristics, which is here the unspecial supplied energy.
Again.
After deploying such a simulation based optimization procedure, we are provide another form of nice, let's say input for the decision maker for the designer.
In this case, this is the results shown in the objective space.
Actually, these are the tradeoffs between the costs and the unsupplied energy.
So we see for how much money or how much one needs to invest in order to come to a certain.

A percentage of these supplied energy, or unsurprised energy, so actually we can then analyze these solutions like this C1 to C5 in the space of variables in the decision space and see what are actually the components needed.
So this actually supplies or supports the decision-making process in the design.
In the design stage of such a project, another.
Possibility that is also present here is supporting this sensitivity analysis.
So we saw this original scenario with a given, let's say energy consumption needed with a certain costs assumed for the lifespan of this system.
One can of course only predict certain parameters like the cost of the fuel for the diesel aggregate and the cost of components and maintain maintenance.
But one can do based on such a multi objective simulation based optimization.
Sensitivity analysis.
So what if analysis?
So how about if the demand for energy decreases for a certain amount, or if it decreases?
We get different tradeoffs for these designs, so these are kinds of tools that we provide to our.
Users to our customers.
So to summarize, to summarize, at the end I will be faster than, so I think that we agree that AI certainly has great potential in manufacturing Ottonian manufacturing.
But actually many fields as we saw today.
But of course, do not expect unmanned factories to operate autonomously today or tomorrow.

One should rather count on the interaction between humans and technology, so actually AI is going to free us of, let's say, a routine tasks and let us more focused on more creative task on higher level tasks and so on.
So I would say, and this is not only my opinion, I see this quite often that most of the successful applications of AI in many mRNA facturing.
Are in the form of either prototypes, testbeds, or small scale projects.
Not full scale projects because this is perceived by many companies.
Still risky because.
You can, I mean this would involve large reorganizations investments and so on.
So many or in most cases what is taking place is step by step approach.
And by the case studies that I shown, we are contributing to this type of progress and some examples were shown in the presentation so.
Before I conclude, I would just like to acknowledge various partners and funding agencies of our projects, either national or international one, and of course the companies.
We had the opportunity to cooperate with.
With this, I would thank you for your attention.
You mentioned that not many of these applications are fully flat projects.
What is the main limiting factor?
Why?
Why are people not going the full length?
What's stopping them?
Well, the full length would be really what is estimated as.
So to say factor of the future where ideally everything works with as little as possible or even know.
Human attendance, so there are, of course there are reports of some attempts of these type of projects, but it would require.
As I said, huge investments.
It would require a huge changes at a certain point with an uncertain outcome.
So this is seen as a main limiting factor or constraining factor at this point.
Um?
So there is a lot of talk in the context of factories of the future.
There is a lot of talk about digital Twins.
Do you have any experience in this area?
Well, digital Twins is really of course one of these hot.
Well to say buzzwords, which includes like.
A number of, let's say digital components in order to design control monitor manufacturing process.
Now I have experience in let's say to a limited extent like some of these approaches could be considered as part of digital Twins.
So this is something we are trying at least to convince some of our partners to go to this if not at the full scale, at least at the increasing.
Rate, so that's the point now.
